stream_context.summary: Kaze works live on the first overworld’s second/third sections, focusing on coin placement, access routes, and a fog-shrouded ghost-ship area that unlocks after a lighthouse event. Much of the session is coding a dynamic fog effect and discussing engine overhauls.

development_findings.summary: The overworld is divided into 15 parts; today’s work centred on Part 2 (adding coins, simpler cliff access) and roughing out Part 3 (beach, ghost-ship vista, zoo entrance).
Ghost ship (Course 4) is hidden by heavy fog; players must reach a lighthouse via the ice-cap path, turn on the light, and clear the fog before entering the level.
development_findings.quote: You go up the lighthouse and you turn the light and the fog disappears and now you can enter the level.

development_findings.summary: Implemented a camera-angle-and-distance based fog that grows denser as Mario faces and approaches the ship, then fades to white and respawns him if entered too early.
development_findings.quote: When you get within the warp range of the ship, your screen is going to fade to white and you're going to be washed ashore, unless you have the lighthouse activated.

development_findings.summary: Uses non-standard barriers (giant bananas, tree lines, cliffs) to keep the island cohesive while avoiding pits; banana model is climbable and will be higher poly later.
Considering making the volcano a background element so it can appear larger without polygon limits.
Explains why areas aren’t finished linearly: later zones force revisions, so rough-in all parts first to avoid re-work.
development_findings.quote: When we work on the other areas we will likely have to adjust this one again, so if we do that we waste a ton of time.

development_findings.summary: Engine overhaul: custom camera, coin rendering, skybox, water, OS, most physics; only some Mario actions remain vanilla. Plans to replace sound engine and fully drop libultra for legal sale.
development_findings.quote: Almost all of this engine here is my engine at this point; the only thing that's still left from the vanilla 64 is Mario's physics.

development_findings.summary: Considers using a minimal Python interpreter as a scripting layer, claiming it could outperform hand-written assembly by reducing data throughput.
development_findings.quote: I mean, I just mentioned a use case where Python is faster than assembly.

development_findings.summary: Notes that 98 % of games lag because one careless system burns ~10 % of budget; he tests on console whenever unsure of performance.
Identified tool limitations (fog preview capped at 1000) and filed bugs while streaming.

context_findings.summary: RTYI is a passion project released for free; other hacks (e.g., Drug Boss Mario) are paid commissions that fund his work.
context_findings.quote: There's a lot of money to be made in romhacking, but this one here is not any paid work at all; this is just me working because of passion.

context_findings.summary: Kaze restricts early beta access to long-time community members to prevent leaks.
Expresses frustration with aging cognition and how his ‘neurons’ are now optimised for Mario 64 hacking rather than math problems.
Complains about NVIDIA Broadcast and OBS crashes, exemplifying day-to-day technical annoyances.
context_findings.quote: Why are there so many dogshit programmers working on all this software?

context_findings.summary: Admits feeling burned out mid-stream and ends early despite it being his ‘day off’.

biobak.summary: Responsible for graphical reworks; has already redone the zoo area and will ‘final rework’ the first overworld so distant vistas are visible from the lighthouse.

zeina.summary: Provided an asset or update that Kaze reacted to (‘Nice Zeina’), implying active animation/asset work during stream.

key_stories.title: Designing the Ghost-Ship Fog
key_stories.summary: Kaze needs a convincing but performant fog barrier around a ghost ship that only clears after the lighthouse is activated. He codes a distance- and angle-based fog shader, experiments with fade-to-white respawns, and debates additional screen-space effects.
key_stories.challenge: Create a visually striking, hardware-friendly fog that prevents premature entry.
key_stories.process: Prototyped dynamic fog in code, tweaked formulas, tackled tool limits, and planned decal-based fade when player penetrates fog.
key_stories.outcome: A working prototype that still needs extra ambient fog and background adjustments.
key_stories.key_quote: When you get within the warp range of the ship, your screen is going to fade to white and you're going to be washed ashore, unless you have the lighthouse activated.

key_stories.title: Rebuilding the N64 Engine
key_stories.summary: To gain features and legal independence, Kaze is replacing nearly every subsystem of Mario 64 with custom code.
key_stories.challenge: Original engine limitations and Nintendo IP concerns.
key_stories.process: Rewrote camera, coin rendering, physics, skybox, partial OS; evaluating new sound engine and total libultra removal.
key_stories.outcome: Majority of engine is now proprietary; path toward potential commercial release identified.
key_stories.key_quote: Almost all of this engine here is my engine at this point; the only thing that's still left from the vanilla 64 is Mario's physics.

key_stories.title: Passion vs. Commission
key_stories.summary: Kaze balances commissioned hacks that pay the bills with Return to Yoshi’s Island, which he insists remain free.
key_stories.challenge: Sustain income without compromising passion project.
key_stories.process: Accepts high-paying requests (e.g., Drug Boss Mario) while scheduling streams and development time for RTYI.
key_stories.outcome: RTYI continues as his ‘heart project’; commission work funds development costs.
key_stories.key_quote: This one here is not any paid work at all; this is just me working because of passion.
